posts.name: Dylan
posts.cooked: Are PowerPole adapter boards recommended to run, or is it fine without?

The connector boards can make your life easier or hell depending on how you use them. Andersons are only as good as the crimps you apply to them, so they must be tested thoroughly. My team connected cables using Andersons directly to the PDP without any intermediaries. Each time I teach students how to crimp Andersons, I remind them, "I'm making this seem simple, but it won't be easy for you." Alongside demonstrating strip length calculations, I focus on teaching them effective crimping techniques.

We found the connection boards to be more trouble than they are worth. They are nice because it’s super easy to power the cancoders right off the motor. However, if you don’t get those molex connectors just right, you’ll have problems—like occasionally losing our drive system (CAN). We never had any problem with the Anderson connectors. During the off-season, we switched to running wires directly to the screw terminals on the kraken, which slowed down a module exchange but increased overall reliability.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: I deeply desired to cherish the Anderson+CAN+power adapter boards due to their +power feature. Regretfully, they were scarce—only four sets across the entire robot. While the ring terminal direct run works well for the Kraken, my children messed up one of the locking molex connectors. These connectors are notoriously finicky; even with the Molex professional tool, adjusting the strip length requires precision. Additionally, the adapter boards share the same Torx hole on both screw sides, which poses a risk if the wrong torque tool is used. This was an ill thought-out choice, as the Kraken's screws are correctly designed with Torx coding based on screw size. Next year, I won't purchase these adapters; instead, we'll operate the corners at half power.

posts.name: Dylan
posts.cooked: Would you say the convenience of the Kraken X60 PowerPole adapters are worth the cost for ease of connection?

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked: As someone who relies on Anderson PowerPoles for various needs, we consistently use the screw terminals on our Kraken devices to maintain a reliable connection when using recommended torque wrenches. These components have proven durable and effective so far. Additionally, if needed, regular Anderson connectors can be added to the cables themselves. A key advantage of Anderson adapters lies in their inclusion of power and CAN (Controller Area Network) connections for sensors, such as those used in swerve platforms, enhancing functionality when applicable.

posts.name: Dylan
posts.cooked: Are there many downsides to not using the Kraken PowerPole Adapters, such as arcing or unexpected brownouts because a screw from the screw terminals isn't tightened properly or comes loose during a match?

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked: We’ve never observed any arcing or screws backing out during a match. As part of our pit checklist, we do go through and check the screws periodically (like when we have a long break between matches) as a precaution, but again we’ve never had any issues during a match that was caused by loose screws.

posts.name: Jimmy McCosker
posts.cooked: The screw terminals not being tightened properly or them coming loose during a match is a significant concern. CTRE, which sells pre-set torque wrenches, offers a solution by preventing such issues. These wrenches provide precision for the Kraken X60 power and CAN leads, ensuring consistent and accurate terminal connections. They also feature audible feedback to alert users when terminals are properly tightened. Available at $29.99, these wrenches are ideal for FRC teams, robotics projects, and electronics assembly.

link_counts.title: Pre-Set Torque Wrench – Precision Tool for Kraken X60 – CTR Electronics

posts.cooked:
We had one motor experience both screws coming loose during our third event on one of our swerve modules. Given that the issue occurred to just one motor, I think it was likely due to a quality control oversight—either not using the right torque wrench or forgetting to tighten the screws properly. Following this incident, we examined all other screws on the motors, and they were all properly tightened.

My current understanding is that ensuring each screw is correctly torqued with the appropriate tools results in reliable connections. As with other components in the electrical system, maintaining attention to detail and enforcing quality control standards are crucial.

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked:
We had one motor whose screws came loose during our third event on a swerve module due to improper torque control. We believe it was either a faulty torque wrench or inadequate torque application.  

One advice we received from CTRE was to attach Torx drivers to torque wrenches to prevent accidental mixing. Additionally, we purchased extra drivers and manual Torx wrenches for easier screw removal, although CTRE wrenches are convenient for tightening but less ergonomic for repetitive use.

posts.name: Chris Herzog
posts.cooked: One thing we were advised to do by someone at CTRE when we got our wrenches is to actually glue the torx drivers into their corresponding torque wrenches so they can’t be mixed up accidentally. I used some adhesive-lined heat shrink over both the shaft and the insert because I had the same concern.
